Suryakumar Yadav.analysis: The 360-degree genius. He doesn't look at the field; he sets it for the bowler. Unstoppable.

Abhishek Sharma.analysis: Explosive talent, but "dil mange more" consistency. He hits hard but gets out too fast sometimes.

Tilak Varma.analysis: A compact player with a cool head. He is the bridge between the top order and the finishers.

Sanju Samson.analysis: So much talent, but often gifts his wicket. A luxury player—beautiful to watch, frustrating to own.

Shivam Dube.analysis: The spin-destroyer! He stands tall and delivers into the second tier. Limited footwork, maximum impact.

Ishan Kishan.analysis: A pocket dynamo who has lost his rhythm. If he clicks, he is a match-winner; if not, he is a dot-ball machine.

Hardik Pandya.analysis: Form is temporary, class is permanent. He balances the side like no one else. The ultimate clutch player.

Arshdeep Singh.analysis: The "Paaji" of death overs. He swings it upfront and nails yorkers at the end. Very reliable.

Jasprit Bumrah.analysis: The cheat code. It's unfair to the batters. Put all your money here and sleep peacefully.

Harshit Rana.analysis: Aggressive and raw. He has the fire, but needs to control the flame to avoid leaking runs.

Varun Chakaravarthy.analysis: The mystery is back! On his day, he runs through the batting lineup like a hot knife through butter.

Kuldeep Yadav.analysis: A magician. He spins a web that traps even the best. A guaranteed wicket-taker in middle overs.

Axar Patel.analysis: "Bapu" does it all. Economical bowling, smart batting, and gun fielding. A manager's dream.

Washington Sundar.analysis: Powerplay specialist with the ball, but his batting in T20s is still a work in progress.

Rinku Singh.analysis: The finisher. Ice in his veins. If you need 20 off the last over, Rinku is the man you call.

Babar Azam.analysis: A run-machine, but the gears can be slow. Buy him for stability, not for 200 strike rate fireworks.

Mohammad Rizwan.analysis: The warrior. He runs, he keeps, he anchors. He will give you fantasy points every single match.

Shaheen Afridi.analysis: The Eagle strikes early! His first over is the most dangerous event in cricket.

Naseem Shah.analysis: Pace, swing, and passion. He has become a complete bowler who can handle pressure.

Haris Rauf.analysis: Pace is high, but so is the economy rate sometimes. A high-risk option who can leak runs.

Shadab Khan.analysis: Currently a shadow of his former self. Full tosses and low confidence make him a risky buy.

Fakhar Zaman.analysis: "Fakhar-e-Pakistan" is hit or miss. If he hits, he wins it; if he misses, he's gone for a duck.

Saim Ayub.analysis: Stylish shots, but needs more substance. The "no-look" shot doesn't help if you don't score runs.

Usman Khan.analysis: PSL hero, but international struggles are real. Not ready for the big boys yet.

Imad Wasim.analysis: Very smart new-ball bowler and lower-order bat. A clever tactical pick for specific conditions.

Abrar Ahmed.analysis: "Harry Potter" spins it both ways. Good mystery option, but fielding is a liability.

Abbas Afridi.analysis: A variation specialist. Good back-of-the-hand slower ball, but lacks raw pace dominance.

Azam Khan.analysis: Hits spin hard, but fitness and pace bowling are his kryptonite. Too many limitations.

Iftikhar Ahmed.analysis: "Chacha" is aging. The power is fading and the fielding is slowing down.

Mohammad Amir.analysis: The veteran still has skills. He knows how to bowl at the death, but he's not a strike bowler anymore.

Scott Edwards.analysis: Captain Courageous! He sweeps everything. Great leader, but limited power game.

Colin Ackermann.analysis: Solid county pro. He gives stability, but won't win you a T20 match single-handedly.

Noah Croes.analysis: Just a backup keeper. Lacks the big hitting required for a fantasy slot.

Bas de Leede.analysis: One-man army for the Dutch. Bowls heavy pace and bats top 4. Excellent value.

Aryan Dutt.analysis: Tall off-spinner who bowls in the powerplay. Very annoying for batters, which is good for you.

Fred Klaassen.analysis: Decent left-arm pacer, but lacks the X-factor to trouble top teams consistently.

Kyle Klein.analysis: Too young, too raw. Needs a few more years of development.

Michael Levitt.analysis: Has potential to hit clean, but hasn't proven it against top-quality spin yet.

Zach Lion-Cachet.analysis: A developmental player. You need match-winners, not interns.

Max O'Dowd.analysis: Solid anchor, but eats up too many dot balls. T20 has moved past his style.

Logan van Beek.analysis: Super Over hero! He brings energy, wickets, and cameos. A very handy utility player.

Timm van der Gugten.analysis: Experience is there, but the pace has dropped. Batter fodder on good wickets.

Roelof van der Merwe.analysis: The Bulldog fights hard, but father time remains undefeated.

Paul van Meekeren.analysis: Skiddy pacer, but can be erratic. Not reliable enough for a 15-man squad.

Saqib Zulfiqar.analysis: A bits and pieces player who doesn't do enough of either to warrant a buy.

Gerhard Erasmus.analysis: The backbone of Namibia. A calm leader who chips in with bat and ball. Solid bench option.

Zane Green.analysis: Struggles to rotate strike. Wicket-keeping is fine, batting is too slow.

Bernard Scholtz.analysis: Very disciplined left-arm spinner. He won't run through a side, but he won't leak runs either.

Ruben Trumpelmann.analysis: Dangerous with the new ball. If it swings, he is a menace. If not, he is average.

JJ Smit.analysis: Injuries have reduced his bowling. As a pure batter, he isn't consistent enough.

Jan Frylinck.analysis: Clever slower balls, but easy to line up on flat tracks.

Louren Steenkamp.analysis: Not up to international standard yet. Better options available.

Malan Kruger.analysis: Another domestic batter who struggles against high pace.

Nicol Loftie-Eaton.analysis: Hit a record century, but has done nothing since. Too inconsistent.

Jack Brassell.analysis: A kid learning the game. Save your money for proven talent.

Ben Shikongo.analysis: Backup pacer. No standout weapons to threaten batters.

JC Balt.analysis: Very new to the scene. Let him play more domestic cricket first.

Dylan Leicher.analysis: A developmental prospect. Not ready for the auction pressure.

WP Myburgh.analysis: A squad player for Namibia, unlikely to break into your 15.

Max Heingo.analysis: Another backup bowling option. Only relevant if you are building a Namibia-specific XI.

Monank Patel.analysis: Good captain and anchor, but lacks the power hitting for a premium slot.

Aaron Jones.analysis: "Jones the Giant" has power, but he goes missing for long stretches.

Saurabh Netravalkar.analysis: The Oracle! A software engineer who codes wickets. Genuine swing and smarts makes him a good player.

Andries Gous.analysis: Classy batter, plays pace well. A very decent backup top-order option.

Harmeet Singh.analysis: Decent spin, but his batting is hit or miss. Not an impact player.

Shayan Jahangir.analysis: Gets stuck at the crease too often. Needs to improve strike rotation.

Milind Kumar.analysis: Ranji veteran, but plays T20s at ODI speed. Not dynamic enough.

Nosthush Kenjige.analysis: Disciplined spinner. Good value for turning tracks, but limited otherwise.

Ali Khan.analysis: The Yorker machine. Good for death overs, but can be expensive if he misses his length.

Jasdeep Singh.analysis: Honest trier, but lacks quality to trouble top batters.

Smit Patel.analysis: Not playing enough high-level cricket to justify a spot.

Abhishek Paradkar.analysis: Young left-arm seamer. Needs more exposure before buying.

Yasir Mohammad.analysis: A squad player. Not enough data to suggest impact.

Juanoy Drysdale.analysis: Raw pace, but inexperienced. A liability in pressure situations.

Mitchell Marsh.analysis: A beast with the bat, but without bowling, he's just a batter. High price for a half-player right now.

Pat Cummins.analysis: The Silencer! He knows how to win. He brings leadership and lower-order hitting.

Travis Head.analysis: He eats bowlers for breakfast. Powerplay destruction guaranteed.

Glenn Maxwell.analysis: The Big Show! Even if he is risky, his ceiling is too high to ignore. A match-winner.

Adam Zampa.analysis: The best white-ball spinner. He takes wickets when nothing else is happening.

Josh Hazlewood.analysis: Metronome. He lands the ball on a coin. Boring, consistent, and effective.

Nathan Ellis.analysis: Skiddy death bowler with good variations. A very smart budget pick.

Josh Inglis.analysis: Innovative and modern. He plays 360 degrees and keeps wicket beautifully.

Marcus Stoinis.analysis: The Hulk! Muscles the ball over the ropes and breaks partnerships. Impact player.

Tim David.analysis: A backend specialist. He doesn't need time; he just needs the ball.

Cameron Green.analysis: Immense talent, but back issues make him a risky investment.

Xavier Bartlett.analysis: Swing king from the BBL. Great new ball option on a budget.

Cooper Connolly.analysis: One for the future, not for today's war room.

Matthew Kuhnemann.analysis: Decent spinner, but you can find better international options.

Matthew Short.analysis: BBL superstar who hasn't cracked international cricket yet.

Dasun Shanaka.analysis: His batting has fallen off a cliff. Not worth the slot.

Pathum Nissanka.analysis: Silent warrior. He scores runs while others collapse. Very reliable.

Kusal Mendis.analysis: When hot, he sizzles. When cold, he freezes. Too inconsistent for a "Safe Buy".

Charith Asalanka.analysis: Gritty middle-order player. Good against spin, but not a power hitter.

Wanindu Hasaranga.analysis: A wicket-taking machine. You simply have to buy him for his strike rate.

Maheesh Theekshana.analysis: Mystery spin in the powerplay. Very hard to hit.

Matheesha Pathirana.analysis: Baby Malinga. His death bowling is world-class. A must-have asset.

Dunith Wellalage.analysis: Young and talented, but lacks the power game for T20s.

Nuwan Thushara.analysis: Malinga 2.0. Good replacement if you miss out on Pathirana.

Kusal Perera.analysis: Made of glass. Great hitter, but always injured.

Dhananjaya de Silva.analysis: A Test player trying to play T20. Too slow.

Kamindu Mendis.analysis: Ambidextrous bowler! A unique package who can bat well too.

Janith Liyanage.analysis: Not enough T20 pedigree to make the cut.

Milan Rathnayake.analysis: Raw pace, but no control. Avoid.

Niroshan Dickwella.analysis: Plays one scoop shot and gets out. Waste of a wicket.

Sikandar Raza.analysis: The spirit of Zimbabwe. He does everything—bat, bowl, field, captain.

Blessing Muzarabani.analysis: Tall, hits the deck hard. A solid budget pacer.

Richard Ngarava.analysis: Left-arm swing. Very tidy bowler for the price.

Brian Bennett.analysis: Developing talent. Not ready for the big stage.

Ryan Burl.analysis: Can hit big and bowl leg-spin, but goes missing too often.

Clive Madande.analysis: Decent finisher, but struggles against high pace.

Tinotenda Maposa.analysis: A young seamer. Needs more time in the domestic circuit.

Tadiwanashe Marumani.analysis: Has talent but hasn't converted it into runs. Too risky.

Wellington Masakadza.analysis: Defensive spinner. Won't win you matches.

Tony Munyonga.analysis: A fringe player. Not enough impact to warrant a slot.

Bradley Evans.analysis: Bits and pieces player who isn't quite good enough at either.

Tashinga Musekiwa.analysis: A finisher who can bowl, but unproven at the top level.

Brendan Taylor.analysis: Legend, but retired. Keep your paddle down.

Paul Stirling.analysis: "Stirlo" is an Irish giant. He hits hard, but age and fitness are catching up.

Mark Adair.analysis: A genuine wicket-taker. Breaks partnerships and whacks sixes at the end.

Ross Adair.analysis: Aggressive but very hit-or-miss. Too risky for an opening slot.

Curtis Campher.analysis: Scrappy cricketer who fights hard, but lacks a standout weapon.

Gareth Delany.analysis: Leg spin is okay, batting is thin. Faded a bit recently.

George Dockrell.analysis: Smart finisher, but lacks the power for a top-tier role.

Josh Little.analysis: IPL quality left-armer. Hits the pitch hard and is reliable.

Barry McCarthy.analysis: Gives 100%, but his bowling can be fodder for big hitters.

Harry Tector.analysis: Technically gifted, plays spin well. A touch of class, if not power.

Lorcan Tucker.analysis: Busy player who loves the scoop. Keeps the scoreboard moving.

Craig Young.analysis: Hit-the-deck bowler but lacks variation. Good depth player only.

Ben White.analysis: Leg-spinner who often bowls too short. Needs more control.

Matthew Humphreys.analysis: Young left-arm spinner. One for the future.

Ben Calitz.analysis: Not a known commodity in international T20s yet.

Jatinder Singh.analysis: Muscle man pose is great, but batting is often slow and scratchy.

Vinayak Shukla.analysis: Domestic performer, but untested against the big boys.

Mohammad Nadeem.analysis: Steady bowler and batter, but lacks the X-factor.

Shakeel Ahmad.analysis: Slow left-arm orthodox. Only useful on a raging turner.

Hammad Mirza.analysis: Not enough impact to make the list.

Wasim Ali.analysis: Squad player only. Doesn't offer enough value.

Karan Sonavale.analysis: Not good enough for this auction.

Shah Faisal.analysis: Average pace, no swing. Easy to line up.

Nadeem Khan.analysis: Doesn't have the power game for modern T20s.

Sufyan Mehmood.analysis: Average seamer. Doesn't threaten the stumps enough.

Jiten Ramanandi.analysis: Bits and pieces, but not enough bits.

Harry Brook.analysis: Modern genius. Shots all around the ground. A pillar for your batting.

Jos Buttler.analysis: Jos the Boss! Destroys attacks with a smile. Essential pick.

Phil Salt.analysis: One gear: Attack. Can win the match in the first 6 overs.

Jofra Archer.analysis: Effortless pace, but injury prone. High risk, high reward.

Adil Rashid.analysis: T20 wizard. Variations even the best struggle to pick.

Sam Curran.analysis: Swings the new ball, clutch at death. A steal at this price.

Liam Dawson.analysis: "Professor" of spin. Economical and smart. Great budget pick.

Will Jacks.analysis: Violent striker and handy off-spin. Match-winner in the making.

Ben Duckett.analysis: Sweeps everything! Good against spin, but lacks power against pace.

Rehan Ahmed.analysis: Young leggie with swagger. Promising but can be expensive.

Tom Banton.analysis: Hockey shots on a cricket field. Talented but inconsistent.

Jacob Bethell.analysis: The next big thing! Dynamic lefty. Buy before his stock rises.

Jamie Overton.analysis: Fast bowling all-rounder who hits miles. Great impact player.

Josh Tongue.analysis: Red-ball specialist. Too one-dimensional for T20.

Luke Wood.analysis: Left-arm pace is in demand, but can be predictable.

Rovman Powell.analysis: Calm captain who hits monster sixes. Handles spin well.

Nicholas Pooran.analysis: Cleanest hitter. When in flow, he wins matches alone. Superstar.

Andre Russell.analysis: Muscle Russell is royalty. Strikes at 180, takes wickets. Mandatory.

Alzarri Joseph.analysis: Fast, angry, effective. Hits the deck hard. Strike bowler.

Akeal Hosein.analysis: Powerplay spin specialist. Disciplined and creates pressure.

Shai Hope.analysis: Classy anchor, but can slow the game down. Situational.

Brandon King.analysis: Elegant and powerful opener. Sets the platform well.

Sherfane Rutherford.analysis: Serious finisher. Has played some blinders recently.

Gudakesh Motie.analysis: Underrated gem! Left-arm spin that grips. Should be priced higher.

Johnson Charles.analysis: Stand and deliver. Minimal footwork, maximum power.

Romario Shepherd.analysis: Hits big, but bowling can be expensive at the death.

Roston Chase.analysis: The "glue" man. Stabilizes collapses and bowls handy off-spin.

Shimron Hetmyer.analysis: Immense talent, but fitness and position fluctuate. Gamble.

Obed McCoy.analysis: Great back-of-hand slower ball, but injuries plague him.

Shamar Joseph.analysis: Gabba hero! Raw in T20s, but has the X-factor.

Litton Das.analysis: Looks like a million dollars, then throws it away. Frustrating.

Tanzid Hasan.analysis: Young opener who attacks, but lacks temperament.

Tawhid Hridoy.analysis: Best young batter in Bangladesh. Rotates strike well.

Taskin Ahmed.analysis: Bowls with heart and pace. Genuine wicket-taker.

Mustafizur Rahman.analysis: "The Fizz"! On slow pitches, he is a king.

Shoriful Islam.analysis: Tall left-armer who swings it. Aggressive upfront.

Rishad Hossain.analysis: Leg-spinner who can bat! Rare find for Bangladesh.

Nasum Ahmed.analysis: Powerplay dart master. Tight lines but few wickets.

Mahedi Hasan.analysis: Utility cricketer. Average at both disciplines.

Tanzim Sakib.analysis: Aggressive pacer, sometimes too much. Prone to leaking runs.

Parvez Hossain Emon.analysis: Young top-order batter. Not consistent enough.

Saif Hassan.analysis: Tried and tested, failed at T20I level.

Shamim Hossain.analysis: Lefty finisher who struggles to finish games.

Nurul Hasan.analysis: Brilliant keeper, but batting is barely serviceable.

Wayne Madsen.analysis: County legend, but too old for a dynamic T20 squad.

JJ Smuts.analysis: Solid domestic player. Offers stability but no fireworks.

Thomas Draca.analysis: Not enough data to justify a spot.

Grant Stewart.analysis: County pro, decent hitter, but not an international star.

Benjamin Manenti.analysis: Doesn't offer enough with bat or ball.

Marcus Campopiano.analysis: Club level stats don't translate here.

Justin Mosca.analysis: Sibling duo, but neither makes the cut.

Rohit Paudel.analysis: Young captain, solid technique, but struggles to accelerate.

Sandeep Lamichhane.analysis: Proven wicket-taker, but lack of recent game time is risky.

Dipendra Singh Airee.analysis: "Tiger"! Gun fielder, handy bowler, explosive finisher.

Kushal Bhurtel.analysis: Aggressive but too hit-or-miss for a main squad.

Aasif Sheikh.analysis: Steady opener, but T20 demands more than "steady".

Sompal Kami.analysis: Veteran all-rounder, backup option at best.

Karan KC.analysis: Lusty blows down the order, but bowling is expensive.

Gulshan Jha.analysis: Very young, high potential, but too raw right now.

Lalit Rajbanshi.analysis: Tidy spinner on turners, offers nothing else.

Basir Ahamad.analysis: Jack of all trades, master of none.

Aiden Markram.analysis: Classy batter, astute captain, useful spinner. Safe pick.

Quinton de Kock.analysis: Match-winner. Explosive starts guaranteed. Elite T20 game.

Kagiso Rabada.analysis: Rabada ka wada! Pace, bounce, wickets. Leader of the pack.

David Miller.analysis: "Killer Miller". Finishes games for fun. Big match player.

Heinrich Klaasen.analysis: Best spin-basher in the world. Terrifying to bowl to.

Marco Jansen.analysis: 7-foot giant. Swings new ball, hits massive sixes. Complete package.

Anrich Nortje.analysis: Fastest in the world when fit, but rusty after injuries.

Keshav Maharaj.analysis: Disciplined captain. Strangles batters in powerplay. Reliable.

Dewald Brevis.analysis: "Baby AB". Huge talent, but inconsistent. High ceiling.

Kwena Maphaka.analysis: 17-year-old prodigy! Fast left-arm pace. Future superstar.

Tony de Zorzi.analysis: Better suited to ODIs than T20s.

Donovan Ferreira.analysis: Multi-utility. Keeps, bowls off-spin, hits miles. Value.

Lungi Ngidi.analysis: Good slower ball, but struggles with rhythm. Risky.

George Linde.analysis: Solid but unspectacular. Doesn't grab headlines.

Mitchell Santner.analysis: Economical machine. Never gives easy runs. Smart buy.

Finn Allen.analysis: Hits to moon or gets out first ball. Frustrating but explosive.

Devon Conway.analysis: Mr. Reliable. Bats through while others hit.

Rachin Ravindra.analysis: Breakout star! Classy batting, useful spin. The future.

Daryl Mitchell.analysis: Tough cookie. Absorbs pressure and launches at the end.

Glenn Phillips.analysis: Super-athlete. Keeps, bowls, fields like a leopard. Utility.

Lockie Ferguson.analysis: Express pace, fragile body. Dangerous if he plays.

Matt Henry.analysis: Brilliant new-ball bowler. Wickets in powerplay consistent.

Ish Sodhi.analysis: Tall leg-spinner, turns it, but bowls one bad ball per over.

Michael Bracewell.analysis: "The Beast". Hits clean, bowls tight off-spin. Underrated.

Mark Chapman.analysis: Solid middle-order player. Flies under the radar.

James Neesham.analysis: T20 freelancer. Can win a game, but consistency is enemy.

Adam Milne.analysis: Fast but very injury-prone. Risky backup.

Tim Seifert.analysis: Cheeky player, loves the scoop. Good backup keeper.

Rashid Khan.analysis: MVP of T20. Bats, fields, best spinner on planet.

Rahmanullah Gurbaz.analysis: Fire and ice (mostly fire). Dangerous opener.

Ibrahim Zadran.analysis: The anchor. Technically solid, prevents collapses.

Azmatullah Omarzai.analysis: Gem! Swings new ball, bats with power. A steal.

Mohammad Nabi.analysis: "The President". Vast experience, but slowing down.

Fazalhaq Farooqi.analysis: Lethal in powerplay. Swings it to destroy top order.

Naveen-ul-Haq.analysis: Master of slower balls. Clever at the death.

Mujeeb Ur Rahman.analysis: Mystery fading, fitness erratic. High risk.

Noor Ahmad.analysis: Left-arm wrist spin is gold. Young and wicket-taking.

Gulbadin Naib.analysis: Strong as an ox, "Vibes" player. Inconsistent skills.

Dilpreet Bajwa.analysis: Hard-hitter, but pool is too deep for him.

Nicholas Kirton.analysis: Lefty with class. Impressive in World Cup. Worth a punt.

Saad Bin Zafar.analysis: Experienced, economical spinner. Doesn't take many wickets.

Kaleem Sana.analysis: Decent left-arm pacer, but bench warmer here.

Navneet Dhaliwal.analysis: Good opener for Canada, won't make your XI.

Dilon Heyliger.analysis: Can hit long ball, bowl medium pace. Bits and pieces.

Muhammad Waseem.analysis: Best Associate batter? Hits sixes for fun. Budget opener.

Vriitya Aravind.analysis: Technically sound but too slow for T20. Anchor.

Asif Khan.analysis: Inconsistent in T20s despite ODI records.

Alishan Sharafu.analysis: Young talent, looks good but doesn't score big.

Aayan Afzal Khan.analysis: Very young, smart left-arm spinner. Good head on shoulders.

Junaid Siddique.analysis: Aggressive pacer. Good yorkers, loses cool sometimes.

Ali Naseer.analysis: Young all-rounder with potential. Watch him.

Karthik Meiyappan.analysis: Faded away after hat-trick vs SL.

Muhammad Jawadullah.analysis: Left-arm seamer, decent prospect but not ready.
